feed.title: 雪中印
feed.subtitle: 心底清静方为道 退步原来是向前

entry.title: Prototype in Javascript
entry.content:
Prototype

The prototype system follows the delegation pattern rather than the traditional class pattern

Constructor Call

  • Objects are created by contructor call (using new)
  • Constructor is used to producing instances that link properties and methods define in the constructor and link to prototype.
  • 2 Kinds of code reuse:
    • Non-static: One happens in the constructor: copy values
    • Static: Another happens in the prototype chain: copy references

Old School

Prototype Chain

  • contructor is only a name, it’s not like the constructor in other programming language, like java
  • Contructor function has only one instance, prototype only has one instance, but the objects, essentially the execution context has many.

对象创建的过程，其实是使用同一构造器，创建不同execution context的过程。

Dunder Prototype

  • deepJS doesn’t have a property called constructor, so it goes up to its prototype and then it could find it, which is the Workshop function
  • deepJS doesn’t have the dunder property, so it goes up its prototype, but found nothing called __proto__, so it continues to go up to the Object’s prototype and then found it! But, unexpectedly ,the __proto__ is actually a function, not a state, it’s a getter function. deepJS.__proto__ will use the deepJS as execution context and get the prototype of deepJS.
  • Infinite Recursion
  • Fix using Dunder Proto

Inheritance

  • Prototypal Inheritance

原型链向上查找的过程并不会改变this的指向

  • Class Inheritance

Class Inheritanace

  • Class Inheritanace copies objects;
  • Prototypal inhertiace links objects.

Issues

Override Binding

  • If you have already use bind,
  • You can only use new to override the binding object;

prototype on Arrow Function

  • Arrow Function doesn’t have this.
  • Arrow Function doesn’t have any prototype.
  • So you can not call new on an arrow function.

Shadow Prototypes

  • shadow means override.
entry.summary:
Prototype

The prototype system follows the delegation pattern rather than the traditional class pattern

Constructor Call

  • Objects are created by contructor call (using new)
  • Constructor is used to producing instances that link properties and methods define in the constructor and link to prototype.
  • 2 Kinds of code reuse:
    • Non-static: One happens in the constructor: copy values
    • Static: Another happens in the prototype chain: copy references

Old School

entry.title: Object in Javascript
entry.content:
this

A function’s this references the execution context for that call, determined entirely by how the function was called

Scope and Closure

Object and this

Prototype chaining happens after this

with this and call

Namespace Pattern

Namespace Pattern: Implicit Binding

  • this is determined during run time.
  • Implicit Binding is used for code reuse.

Namespace to Explicit binding

Hard binding

new

  • It’s created to call a function with a whole new empty object as the execution context.
  • new means new empty execution context.

Sample

Alternative

  • The same with call()

How it works

  • Create a brand new empty object
  • * Link that object to another object - prototype object
  • Call function with this set to the new object
  • If function does not return an object, assume return of this.

Default Binding

  • no new keyword
  • no call, apply, bind
  • no object context like asd.ask()
  • yes, default binding, is the global; if strict mode, undefined binding.

Precedence in this

  • new
  • call() or apply(), bind()
  • context object for example workshop.ask()
  • Default binding (except strict mode)

Arrow Function

!this

  • There is no this in arrow function
  • Will lexically resolve the variable from inner to outer scope
  • You can’t use new for an arrow function, because it doesn’t define this keyword.

Function Declaration without this

Function Declaration with this

Arrow Function with this

this in Arrow function behaves lexically, but still relates to this (not its own this);

  • the outside scope is the ask function
  • the outside scope is not the setTimeout because there it encloses with () rather than {}
    • But not all {} are scopes - Object{}
    • function(){} is scope.
  • this of ask function is the workshop object.

it still traces this, but not its own.

Arrow Function without this

  • the outside scope is ask, no teacher
  • the outside scope is global, no teacher
  • undefined.

Class

Class keyword is just a syntax sugar for a layer on top of the prototype system.

Example

Origin

Inheritance

Alternative

super keyword

super is detemined during complile time - lexically scoped

this still dynamic in Class

Constructor

Issues

Why Kyle is not in the global object?

  • global objectis different from global scope
  • closure can happen both on scope or object perspectives
  • this can only happen in the object perspective
  • var teacher is defined in the global scope

Scope and Object

  • teacher trace lexical scope
  • this.teacher trace execution context and then prototype chain

How to identify Scope?

  • this's scope will the be global object rather than workshop because object is not a scope
  • global scope doesn’t have this, so by default it is {};
  • Only function scope has this
entry.summary:
this

A function’s this references the execution context for that call, determined entirely by how the function was called

Scope and Closure

Object and this

Prototype chaining happens after this

entry.title: Closure in Javascript
entry.content:
Closure

Closure is when a function “remembers” its’ lexical scope even when the function is executed outside the lexical scope.

Examples

  • Example 1
  • Example 2

Close over What?

Close over variables rather than values

Interview Questions

  • Output?
  • Output?
  • Output?
  • Why?
  • First one, only one variables and closed over the only value
  • Second one, three variables and closed over respectively.

Module Pattern

Similar to encapsulation

  • Make state as Private
  • Make function as Public
  • Prerequisite: Closure.

Namespace Pattern

Problem: You can still access the teacher directly

Revealing Pattern

Module encapsulate data and behavior together. The state of a module is held by its methods via closure.

  • use IIFE for singleton

Factory Pattern

ES6 Module

  • This is singleton export.
  • Import
entry.summary:
Closure

Closure is when a function “remembers” its’ lexical scope even when the function is executed outside the lexical scope.

Examples

  • Example 1
  • Example 2

entry.title: Scope in Javascript
entry.content:
Scope

Compiler vs Interpreter

  • Reference
  • Compilter: compile source code to machine code and run
  • Interpreter: interpret and run the code at the same time

Javascript is not interpreted langauage. It’s a compiled language with two pass processing. One is compling the code and declare all the scope and left hand things. Another is evaluating the right hand things and run the code eventually.

How Compiler Works

  • Simple
  • Strict Mode Off
  • Strict Mode On
  • Nested Scope

Search from inner to outer not vice versa.

Function Types

  • Function Declaration

function teacher is declared in global scope

  • Named Function Expression

myTeacher is declared in the global scope but function anotherTeacher is declared in the myTeacher scope

  • Anonymous Function Expression
  • Arrow Function

  • Function Types Hierarchy

    • Top 1. (Names) Function Declaration
    • Top 2. Named Function Expression
    • Top 3. Anonymous Function Expression

  • Prefer the Named Function Expression

    • Reason 1: Self-reference for recursion
    • Reason 2: More debuggable stack traces
    • Reason 3: More self-documenting code

IIFE

Immediately Invoked Function Expression

  • Simple
  • normal way of doing async/await with try/catch
  • make assignment happens only once

Block Scoping

  • Create a new Scope

Not all {} creates scopes if they didn’t use const or let

  • Hints!

let and const shows this is a new scope!

  • let vs var
  • use let in block scope
  • use var for reusing, because it can be level up to global.
  • const Usage
  • only use const for primitive immutable values, just like final in Java
  • For non-primitive types, const means this variable cannot be reassigned. But it can be changed. So you don’t have to use const.
  • use Object.freeze() to make an object final in strict-mode

Hoisting

  • javascript engine does not re-organize your code and do the hoisting
  • javascript only parse the code in a different way
  • Variable Declaration
  • After Hoisting
  • Function Declaration
  • After Hoisting
  • let and const on hoisting
  • let hoisted

Commons

Terms

  • Shadowing: have two variables in different scopes with the same name

  • Left and Right Position

    • Left: the variable to be signed a value to
    • Right: the value to be assigned to a varibale.

  • Compile Time

    • declare the left side things

  • Run Time

    • execute the right side things

  • parameter vs argument

    • parameter: left side thing for obtaining values
    • argument: right side thing for extracting values

Lexical Scope

  • AkA: static scope
  • The scope is decided during the compile stage

Dynamic scope

  • The scope is decided in the run stage, depends on the call chain of method.
entry.summary:
Scope

Compiler vs Interpreter

  • Reference
  • Compilter: compile source code to machine code and run
  • Interpreter: interpret and run the code at the same time

Javascript is not interpreted langauage. It’s a compiled language with two pass processing. One is compling the code and declare all the scope and left hand things. Another is evaluating the right hand things and run the code eventually.

How Compiler Works

  • Simple

entry.title: Equality in Javascript
entry.content:
Abastract Equality Comparison

== vs ===

  • SPEC

Only use the == when you know the type especially when implicit coercion is very helpful.

== allows for coercion

  • null equal to undefined.
  • any is number, compare number

=== disallows for coercion

  • use === is safe because it’s for the case that you don’t know the types.

But implicit coercion is faster than you do.

Summary

  • If you know the types, == is better.
  • Otherwise you clould use === for safety.

Be careful of -0 when you use implicit coercion
entry.summary:
Abastract Equality Comparison

== vs ===

  • SPEC

Only use the == when you know the type especially when implicit coercion is very helpful.

== allows for coercion

  • null equal to undefined.
  • any is number, compare number

entry.title: Coercion in Javascript
entry.content:
Abstract Operations

ToPrimitive, ToString, ToNumber, ToBoolean

ToPrimitive(hint)

convert from non-primitive to primitive

  • Hint: number
    • valueOf()
    • toString()
    • valueOf()
  • Hint: string
    • toString()
    • valueOf()
    • toString()

ToString

  • Primitive Type
  • Weird Conversion from Array
  • Weird Conversion from Object
  • Override toString() for object

ToNumber

= ToPrimitive(number)

  • Conversion from primitive type
  • Conversion from non-primitive type

will invoke the toPrimitive(Number) abstract operaiton

  • Override valueOf() for object
  • Operation valueOf()

ToBoolean

ToBoolean only does look up, do not invode any other abstract operations

  • False
    • ""
    • 0, -0
    • null
    • NaN
    • undefined
    • false
  • True
    • "foo"
    • 23
    • {a:'1'}
    • [1,3]
    • function(){...}
    • true
    • …

Explicit Coercion

to string

  • use ${}
  • use +
  • use Array.prototype.join()
  • use toString() of a non-primitive type
  • use String(): Recommended

to number

  • use +
  • use Number(): Recommended

to boolean

  • use !!
  • use Boolean()

Implicit Coercion

Boxing: Wrap primitive types up as Objects

  • Just let the boxing happens which has performance benefits.

Corner Case
entry.summary:
Abstract Operations

ToPrimitive, ToString, ToNumber, ToBoolean

ToPrimitive(hint)

convert from non-primitive to primitive

  • Hint: number
    • valueOf()
    • toString()
    • valueOf()
  • Hint: string
    • toString()
    • valueOf()
    • toString()

ToString

  • Primitive Type
  • Weird Conversion from Array
  • Weird Conversion from Object
  • Override toString() for object

entry.title: Types in Javascript
entry.content:
Types

In Javascript, statement “every thing is a an object” is wrong. Primitive types are not objects. But some of them can behave like objects.

Primitive Types

In Javascript, variable doesn’t have types, value have.

  • Undefined: created but has no value; default value
  • Null: represents the intentional absence of any object value
  • Boolean: true or false (not 1 and 0); can behave like an object: Boolean
  • Number: NaN, -0, 0，-Infinite, Infiniteand others; can behave like an object: Number
  • String: '' and other; can behave like an object: String
  • Symbol: unique and non-string

Object

a collection of properties; a sinle prototype

  • null
  • array
  • function
  • …

Quick Example

  • Normal Parts
  • Weird Parts
  • Weird Parts Exploration

Emptiness

  • Undeclared; not declared;
  • Uninitialized: declared but cannot be accessed to; Temporal Dead Zone.
  • Undefined declared but has no value;
  • null: an object with value of null;
  • NaN: a number but an invalid number;

Special value

Special NaN

  • String to Number by Number()
  • Equality on NaN
  • isNaN: implicit coercion happens
  • Number.isNaN(): no coercion happens
  • Strict Check
  • Don’t use undefined, null, false, -1, 0 to replace NaN. NaN is the only proper representation of an invalid number.

Special -0

Zero with direction minus

  • Weird Parts
  • Strict check
  • Obtain Direction
  • Custom Direction Getter

Constructor Time

  • You should use new to build constructor when
  • You should avoid new when

Commons:

  • Don’t use MDN, use ecma-262
  • Polyfill Pattern

entry.title: High-Rating Restaurant Search
entry.content:
Project

Github git clone git@github.com:GeekEast/search-good-eat.git

Description

  • Searching api for good restaurants by latitude, longtitude, and radius.
  • Bottomn line of google ratings and number_of_reviews is required.

Warning

  • See the API pricing before happy hour with it.
  • Recommend to apply for a brand new Google account and use the free google cloud credit which’s worth $300.

Quick Start

  • Get API Key: export GOOGLE_MAP_API_KEY="{google_map_api_key}"
  • Run code: yarn && yarn start

Issues:

  • The performance is low due the restriction of Google Places API;
  • How to append object to array asynchronously?.
  • Latitude and Longtitude offset is a estimate.

Result for Adelaide

entry.summary:
Project

Github git clone git@github.com:GeekEast/search-good-eat.git

Description

  • Searching api for good restaurants by latitude, longtitude, and radius.
  • Bottomn line of google ratings and number_of_reviews is required.

Warning

  • See the API pricing before happy hour with it.
  • Recommend to apply for a brand new Google account and use the free google cloud credit which’s worth $300.

Quick Start

  • Get API Key: export GOOGLE_MAP_API_KEY="{google_map_api_key}"
  • Run code: yarn && yarn start

entry.title: Java OOP
entry.content:
Why

  • why we need oop?
  • what is oop?
  • oop is object
  • what is object? toy block!
  • why we need object? building large things
  • why not just build it? because we want to reuse these blocks in the future

Conclusion: Object is used to build for more than once and one kind, and one thing.

Object

  • granule, atom, cell
  • not the object in java, we simple rename it as atom.
  • what is the granule in java?
  • enum, variable, function, class, interface

How to reuse code?

  • example: enum -> variable; make things changable.
  • but change what? kind? value? template?

ENUM

Variable

Function

Class

Interface

Abstract Class
entry.summary:
Why

  • why we need oop?
  • what is oop?
  • oop is object

entry.title: Biology & SOLID
entry.content:
Biology

Cell Core

  • Anything that is not passed from outside
  • Include:
    • Outside: Strong Coupling
    • Self: should be simple, only for one purpose.

Cell Wall

  • Anything that is passed from outside
    • Level 1. primitive: only one type
    • Level 2. function: only one type
    • Level 3. class: any class extends that class(add new parent sometimes)
    • Level 4. interface: any class implements that interface(slim)
    • Level 5. generics: any type extends something (extends = implement)

Decoupling

  • Move Outside things in Cell Core to Cell Wall.
  • Make reference of things in Cell more abstract.

SOLID

Single Responsibility

  • The core of a cell should be pure, simple and only for one purpose.

Open/Close

  • Don’t have to modify core in order to link to other cells.

Liskv Substitution

  • Clothes for children should also be suitable for parents.
  • Solution: make new parents between old parents and the child.

Interface Segregation

  • Enough but not more things in Interface for it to be implemented in class.

Dependency Inversion

  • Cell Wall should use Interface, not class.
entry.summary:
Biology

Cell Core

  • Anything that is not passed from outside
  • Include:
    • Outside: Strong Coupling
    • Self: should be simple, only for one purpose.

Cell Wall

  • Anything that is passed from outside
    • Level 1. primitive: only one type
    • Level 2. function: only one type
    • Level 3. class: any class extends that class(add new parent sometimes)
    • Level 4. interface: any class implements that interface(slim)
    • Level 5. generics: any type extends something (extends = implement)

Decoupling

  • Move Outside things in Cell Core to Cell Wall.
  • Make reference of things in Cell more abstract.

entry.title: AWS Data Insights Learning Series
entry.content:
Architecture

Design Principle for AWS Products

  • Flexibility: Scale in the future
  • 10x Speed: performance really matters
  • De-couple: Infrastructure Reuse
  • Experimental at Scale: Break and Succeed
  • Test and fail fast: Quicker to find the right wat
  • Not invented yest: innovative
  • No more silos: data products are connected
  • Multiple Personas: integrated different jobs
  • Ready for AIML: Support Intelligence

Modern Data Architecture

  1. Data Source
  2. Data Ingest
  3. Batch Data Pipelines
  4. Event Pipelines
  5. Serving
  6. Business Outcomes

Solution Based Learning Paths

Data Lakes

AWS Database and Analytics

  • Business Intelligence & Machine Learning
    • Amazon Quicksight: Dashboard
    • Amazon SageMaker: Develop/Deploy ML Model
    • Amazon Comprehend: Natural Language Processing
    • Amazon Rekognition: Video and Image
    • Amazon Lex: chatbot
    • Amazon Trascribe: Speech Recognition
    • AWS DeepLens: DL enable Video Camera for Devs
  • Database:
    • QLDB: Ledger Database
    • Neptune: Graph Database
    • ElastiCache: Redis, Memcached
    • DynamoDB: Key-value, Document
    • Aurora: MySQL, PostgreSQL
    • Timestream: Time series
    • RDS: MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, Oracle, SQL Server
  • Analytics
    • Amazon Redshift: Data warehousing
    • Athena: Query AWS with SQL
    • EMR: Hadoop and Spark
    • Kinesis: real-time data processing
    • ElasticSearch: Search
  • Data Lake:
    • S3/Glacier: Storage
    • Lake Formation: form lake
    • Glue: ETL, Data catalog
  • Data Movement:
    • Database Migration Service: from database to AWS
    • Snowball: Large Data from/to AWS
    • Snowmobile: Super Large Data from/to AWS
    • Kinesis Data Firehouse: realtime data to storage and analytics.
    • Kinesis Data Streams: collect data at scale for real-time analytics
    • Data Pipeline: data movement and transformation
    • Direct Connect: build network from premises to aws

Sage Maker

AWS Machine Learning Stack

SageMaker Pipeline

Labeling

Models

AWS Robotics
entry.summary:
Architecture

Design Principle for AWS Products

  • Flexibility: Scale in the future
  • 10x Speed: performance really matters
  • De-couple: Infrastructure Reuse
  • Experimental at Scale: Break and Succeed
  • Test and fail fast: Quicker to find the right wat
  • Not invented yest: innovative
  • No more silos: data products are connected
  • Multiple Personas: integrated different jobs
  • Ready for AIML: Support Intelligence

Modern Data Architecture

  1. Data Source
  2. Data Ingest
  3. Batch Data Pipelines
  4. Event Pipelines
  5. Serving
  6. Business Outcomes

entry.title: GitLab CI/CD
entry.content:
Gitlab CI/CD

Concept

Job

  • job: a task that gitlab should do for us
  • For example, we can define build as a job
  • The runner will git clone your repository
  • The default directory is /builds/{username}/{project_name}/
  • By default, Gitlab will run jobs in parallel
  • After git commit, you will see two jobs running concurrently in Gitlab
  • When a specific job fails, you will received the notification in your email

Stage

  • We can define the stages(order) in sequence
  • And you will see the jobs will be executed one after one
  • What if we define two jobs under the same stage?
  • The two jobs will be executed in parallel
  • Conclusion:
    • jobs under same stage in parallel
    • different stages in** sequence**
  • You can see the test job failed, why?!
  • Because the folder build/car.txt doesn’t exist.
  • Jobs are standalone by default, they don’t depend on each other and don’t have communication to each other

Artifact

  • How to save the artifact(result) of one job in order to be shared between jobs?
  • The build folder including the files inside it will be uploaded to the coordinator
  • The next job will download the artifacts from the coordinator

You can download and inspect the artifact in Gitlab!

  • It failed, why?
  • Solution: Use >> instead of > to append files
  • Now it passed
  • Trick: Always remember use ls or cat filename to debug.

Runner

  • Based on docker, you can image that as a linux machine
  • By default, Gitlab use Shared Runners

Image

  • The runner is based on docker, by default in ruby env.
  • What if we want to change the env?
  • Use image, find the image that you want here
  • How to choose image?
    • It can meet your requirements
    • Keep the docker file as small as possible, for example user alpine

Global Image

  • But I have to specify the image for each job!

Job Status

  • success: if the exit status is 0
  • failed: if the exit status is 1-255
  • Debugger skill:

The last green line showed in the gitlab runner is where the test failed.

Blocking

  • Some jobs like start the api server will by default stop the scripts below it from running.
  • Solution: Run in backgroud

Environment Variable

  • You can define env var in Gitlab Project
  • Env varis accessible by gitlab runner
  • Store the secrets in env var

Cache

  • When: used for temporary storage for project dependencies.
  • cache between runnings of pipeline, the bigger the cached files, the more obvious the speed is increasing
  • cache between stages, the more cache shared between stages, the more obvious the speed is increasing
  • When we should use CI_COMMIT_REF_SLUG?
    • In the example, the key of cache is specific to one branch.
    • The CI_COMMIT_REF_SLUG is the key of current branch.
  • Global Cache

Warning: sometimes the cache will cause the job to fail, simply use clear runner caches in gitlab to fix this.

Staging

  • Staging is simply the deployment to a environment for UAT.

Environment

  • Easily to track
  • You could open the environment directly in Gitlab > Operations > Environemnts
  • You can also set as dynamic environment

Variables

  • To store common things that will be used in gitlab runner
  • You can store domain name, for example
  • You could define in gitlab
  • Or you could define in .gitlab-ci.yml

Auto Trigger

  • Anytime you make changes to branches of the gitlab project, it will trigger the CI rule that has been defined in the .gitlab-ci.yml
  • .gitlab-ci.yml can also define the rule for different branches of the project.

Manual Trigger

  • Happens between staging and production
  • Opiton 1: Fully Manually

The job behind the manual job will be automatically failed.

  • If you don’t want the job behind to fail
  • Opiton 1: Branching and Merging
    • For branch develop, we only need build and test, without staging and deploy
    • For branch master, we all jobs to run

On_stop

  • You want to start a runner after one environment stops

Disable job

  • Enable
  • Disable

Reference

Gitlab CI/CD Pipeline Configuration Reference

Gitlab Predefined Environment Variables

Free Personal Static Website Tutorial

Static Website Easy Deploy

Job Templates and Anchor

Boilerplate
entry.summary:
Gitlab CI/CD

Concept

Job

  • job: a task that gitlab should do for us
  • For example, we can define build as a job
  • The runner will git clone your repository
  • The default directory is /builds/{username}/{project_name}/
  • By default, Gitlab will run jobs in parallel
  • After git commit, you will see two jobs running concurrently in Gitlab
  • When a specific job fails, you will received the notification in your email
